A.  The mucin deposits over peritoneal surfaces of omentum and peritoneum sampled show changes of low grade pseudomyxoma peritonei.  Some of the mucin deposits are acellular and have a surrounding foreign body giant cell reaction.  Others contain small amo

ion.  Others contain small amounts of neoplastic mucinous epithelium which is arranged in flat non-complex strips and shows low grade atypia.  No invasion.  No signet ring cell component seen.  Sections of the bowel ends are unremarkable. There is fibrous
nremarkable. There is fibrous scaring in tissue deep to umbilicus.

asures 30 x 25mm and has unremarkable surface. On sectioning, the endometrium is 1mm in maximum thickness and the myometrium is 50mm in maximum thickness.  There is an exophytic pale tumour located at the fundus at the right side of the uterus involving bo

ide of the uterus involving both anterior and posterior wall measuring 18 x 8 x 8mm.  There are multiple fibroids ranging from 10mm in diameter to 20mm in diameter.  There is extensive calcification involving the fibroids.   The right fallopian tube with f

he right fallopian tube with fimbrial measures 65mm in length, 5mm in maximum external dimension.  The right ovary measures 34 x 16 x 7mm and has an unremarkable surface. The left fallopian tube and fimbrial measures 70mm in length, 8mm in maximum dimensio
ength, 8mm in maximum dimension.  The left ovary measures 45 x 15 x 6mm and has an unremarkable surface.

Sections of the uterine tumour show a Grade 1 endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma consists predominantly of complex, crowded glands, some of which have a cribriform morphology, lined by moderately pleomorphic carcinoma cells (FIGO a

orphic carcinoma cells (FIGO architecture grade 1; nuclear grade 2 = overall grade 1). The carcinoma extends 2.2mm into a uterine wall 12mm thick. There is no evidence of lymphovascular space invasion. The carcinoma does not involve the sampled uterine cor
nvolve the sampled uterine cornua.

wing a discussion with Dr Lon GRAYDON over the phone.  The specimen weighs 56g and measures 55mm from medial to lateral, 25mm from superior to inferior, 65mm from superficial to deep.  An ellipse of skin measuring 25 x 10mm is present on the superficial su

present on the superficial surface.  Two hookwires are inserted from the superficial aspect of the specimen.  The lateral surface is inked red, the superior surface is inked blue and the inferior surface is inked black.  The specimen is serially sectioned

specimen is serially sectioned from superficial to deep into twelve slices, slice one superficial slice twelve deep.  On the cut surface a previous biopsy cavity is noted in slices three to eight, filled with foreign body material.  A clip is noted on the
rial.  A clip is noted on the x-ray but was displaced during slicing.  The cut surface of the breast tissue is fatty; no mass is seen.

Blocks: 1 and 2 - LS superficial margin; 3 and 4 - slice two; 5 and 6 - slice three; 7 and 8 - slice four; 9 and 10 - slice five; 11 and 12 - slice six; 13 and 14 - slice seven; 15 to 17 - slice eight; 18 to 20 - slice nine; 21 to 23 - slice ten; 24 and 25
1 to 23 - slice ten; 24 and 25 - slice eleven; 26 and 27 - LS of slice 12 deep margin.  Multiple pieces in 27 blocks.

Sections show breast tissue with a previous biopsy site associated with adjacent fat necrosis.  There is sclerosing adenosis, apocrine metaplasia, and columnar cell change without atypia associated with luminal coarse calcification, and some moderate and f

ation, and some moderate and florid epithelial hyperplasia of usual type.  Stromal calcification is also present.  There is also a single small focus of atypical ductal hyperplasia; this is in the centre of the specimen and is well away from all excision m
well away from all excision margins (block 9).  There is no in-situ or invasive malignancy.

A & B.  Sections show fragments of glioblastoma multiforme with prominentendothelial proliferation and foci of palisaded necrosis.  There are numerous mitoses and the Ki67 is about 30%.  The IDH-1 is negative.  There is also focal venous thrombosis and onl
ocal venous thrombosis and only a small amount of uninvolved brain is present.

SEGMENT 6/7 LIVER RESECTION.  A portion of liver weighing 102g and measuring 80x60x40mm.  On the capsular surface there is a pale irregular lesion which has been previously incised measuring 35mm in diameter.  On sectioning the lesion is solid with some
the lesion is solid with some focal haemorrhage and ?necrosis.  The cross sectional area is up to 28x17mm.  It is located 13mm from the nearest resection margin.

Sections show a 35mm moderately to poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with trabecular and acinar architecture.  Areas of pleomorphic tumour cells including multinucleated forms are present.  Lymphovascular invasion by the carcinoma is present i
by the carcinoma is present in adjacent liver parenchyma.  Focal intracytoplasmic bile production by the carcinoma is present.  Local excision of the carcinoma appears complete.

Immunoperoxidase staining of the tumour cells shows positive staining with Cam5.2  and bile canalicular staining pattern with CD10.  Focal non specific staining with synaptophysin is seen.  No staining for CK20, AE1/AE3, ubiquitin or chromogranin is presen
itin or chromogranin is present.

The adjacent liver parenchyma shows a mild chroic hepatitis B.  There is increased fibrosis including areas of porto-portal bridging fibrosis (F2).  There is mild focal piecemeal necrosis within the portal tracts.  Minimal chronic inflammation is seen in t

onic inflammation is seen in the liver lobules.  Large cell dysplasia of hepatocytes is present and mild macrovesicular steatosis is also seen.  Hepatocyte iron and copper content is not increased.  Immunoperoxidase staining of hepatocytes shows cell membr
f hepatocytes shows cell membrane and cytoplasmic staining with HBsAg and focal intranuclear staining with HBcAg.

Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch r
nactivation of that mismatch repair gene.

y endometrial rather than endocervical carcinoma.  Endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the lower segment is associated with Lynch syndrome.

The three small intestinal tumours show similarmorphology and are composed of cells mainly arranged in solid nests. The tumour cells have fairly uniform nuclei, stippled chromatin and granular eosinophilic cytoplasm, often more accentuated in the periphery

ph node metastases and extranodal deposits show similar morphology tothe intestinal tumours.

large vessel  involvement (block A17) is also present.

A & B.  Sections show a predominantly unencapsulated tumour with no definite connection to adjacent adrenal gland. The tumour shows variable cellularity in which the great majority of cells have an oncocytic appearance with abundant granular pink cytoplasm

undant granular pink cytoplasm.  In less cellular areas tumour cells are separated by mucin or oedema fluid. The tumour cells are arranged in small acinar and trabecular formations with an intervening fine vascular network.  Adipose tissue focally surround

dipose tissue focally surrounds the tumour however deposits of adipose tissue are also seen within the tumour.  Numerous thick walled blood vessels are present.  No convincing spindle cell component is seen.  Although focally some of the tumour cells show

some of the tumour cells show bizarre nuclear pleomorphism, mitoses are extremely rare and the Ki67 index is less than 1%.  In two representative sections (blocks B15 & B16) the oncocytic tumour cells blend with cells which appear adrenocortical in nature
pear adrenocortical in nature with abundant multivacuolated clear cytoplasm.  Focally the diathermied resection margin transects the tumour.

The tumour cells show strong positive staining with vimentin and CD10.  There is moderate staining with NSE and patchy staining with MelanA, PanCK and AE1/3. The EMA, calretinin, inhibin, HMB-45, chromogranin, synaptophysin, CK7, CK20, C-kit, Hepar-1 and S
K7, CK20, C-kit, Hepar-1 and SMA stains are negative.

The differential diagnosis in this case includes an oncocytic adrenocortical neoplasm, epithelioid angiomyolipoma and renal oncocytoma.  The latter is discounted on clinical grounds (not related to adjacentkidney).  Although the tumour contains adipose tis

he tumour contains adipose tissue and thick walled blood vessels, there is insufficient immunohistochemical evidence for an angiomyolipoma. The favoured diagnosis in this case is an oncocytic adrenocortical neoplasm and due to the size, the tumour would be
the size, the tumour would be classified as having borderline malignant potential (Lin-Weiss-Bisceglia criteria).Due to the unusual nature of this tumour a second opinion will be sought.

As you know large adrenal cortical lesions with oncocytic cytologic features are a very problematic and evolving area in pathology. It is clear that theWeiss criteria cannot be applied without modification to oncocytic lesions, therefore other systems such

, therefore other systems such as the Lin-Weiss-Bisceglia system (LWB) have been proposed as has the reticulin algorithm. The reason why so many systems have been proposed is that none have been proven to be completely sensitive and specific.
ve and specific.

Despite its very low mitotic rate and proliferative activity, this adrenal cortical tumour displays several worrying features. Firstly there is quite prominent myxoid change. Myxoid change is not definitive, but is a feature which is suggestive of malignan

hich is suggestive of malignancy as it occurs only very rarely in clinically benign disease (Ref: Am J Surg Pathol 2010, pp973-983). Secondly the tumour is very large. Thirdly the tumour displays a worrying growth pattern including some pseudoglandular are
uding some pseudoglandular areas (another feature which is not definitive but occurs more commonly in malignancies than benign tumours).

We and others have found IGF2 expression to be a very useful marker of adrenal cortical carcinoma and particular useful in identifying tumours with a low proliferative rate (Ref: Endocrine Related Cancer 2009, pp573-583).We have also recently reported that

ve also recently reported that the glucocorticoid receptor over-expressionis a strong marker of low-grade adrenal cortical carcinoma (Ref; Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism 2009, pp4591-4599)- but this finding isyet to be confirmed prospecti
syet to be confirmed prospectively or by another group and so should be considered preliminary.

Therefore on the basis of the very large size of the tumour, the presence of myxoid and pseudoglandular change, and the presence of strong positive staining for both IGF2 and glucocorticoid receptor, I favour this as adrenal cortical carcinoma of myxoid an
ortical carcinoma of myxoid and oncocytic type.

The excision specimen of this low grade myxoid lesion remains difficult. I am still uncertain how to classify this hypo-cellular fibro myxoid lesion within fatty tissue. It is essentially circumscribed and includes hyalinised collagenous areas with scatter

I am not certain of the diagnosis.Possibilities I considered were a well differentiated liposarcoma with myxoid areas, an unusual myxoid liposarcoma, a chondroid lipoma, a cellular myxoma and a low grade fibro myxoid sarcoma. The negative MUC4 immunostain

The negative MUC4 immunostain is against thelatter. The absence of MDM2 amplification on FISH (please see Prof K'Eberling comment below) is against a well differentiated liposarcoma. Further FISH analysis (DDIT3 & FUS) is pending.
ing.

I agree with Prof Tarka differential for this most unusual myoid tumour. Whilst it is not typical of any of them, I slightly favour an unusual chondroid lipoma but definitely could not exclude a low grade sarcoma. I await FISH analysis results with interes

As you rightly say, both lesions have similar morphologic features, being characterised by an acinar-type or papillary proliferation of plump epithelioid cells with palely eosinophilic or clear cytoplasm and relatively uniform and only mildly atypical vesi

and only mildly atypical vesicular nuclei.  While some areasof the lesion do indeed bear an architectural resemblance to myxopapillary ependymoma, the bulk of the lesion has much more epithelioid morphology than one would expect in that context.  Immunost

ect in that context.  Immunostains in our hands show strong positivity not only for S100 protein but also for GFAP along with scattered cells positive EMA and rare cells positive for keratin CAM 5.2, while stains for pan keratin, p63, TFE-2 and Olig 2 are

in, p63, TFE-2 and Olig 2 are negative.  Staining for INI-1 is positive, ie. normal/retained.  I believe that the cytoarchitectural features and immunophenotype would fit best with myoepithelial carcinoma, low grade. The presence of two distinct masses is

nce of two distinct masses is very worrisome and clearly raises the possibility of this representing metastasis from elsewhere, unless perhaps one of these lesions represents a locoregional metastasis from the other.  Only ongoing clinical correlation will
oing clinical correlation will help to address this question.  I would be very interested to hear of future developments in this unusual case".

A & B.  The peritoneal nodule (specimen A) is a malignant spindle cell tumour, composed of moderately pleomorphic spindle cells arranged in cellular fascicles, with numerous admixed atypical mitoses and patchy chronic inflammation. At the edge of the spind

tion. At the edge of the spindle tumour, there are numerous epithelioid to bizarre highly pleomorphic malignant cells. The intra-abdominal tumour (specimen B) is a high grade malignant epithelioid tumour. The tumour is composed of sheets of discohesive, hi
d of sheets of discohesive, highly pleomorphic epithelioid cells, including binucleate, multinucleateand bizarre pleomorphic tumour cells. Mitoses and necrosis are readily identified.

The peritoneal wall and intra-abdominal tumours are malignant spindle cell and epithelioid tumours, respectively. Both tumours have a similar pattern of immunohistochemical staining, and the overall appearance is similar to the retroperitoneal high grade e

e retroperitoneal high grade epithelioid and spindle cell sarcoma previously described in the pathology slide review from South Africa in 2057 (51G89448YRC Worldwide). These peritoneal wall and intra-abdominal tumours most likely represent a spectrum of mo

ely represent a spectrum of morphological atypia within a high grade undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma. Although no lipoblasts are seen, it is possible that these tumours represent foci of dedifferentiated liposarcoma, which could be confirmed with FISH
h could be confirmed with FISH testing for MDM2 amplification.

There is focal S100 staining in the intra-abdominal tumour, and although additional markers of melanoma such as HMB45 and Melan-A are negative and melanoma is considered less likely, the possibility that this tumour represents metastatic malignant melanoma
metastatic malignant melanoma cannot be entirely excluded.

Only 5 metaphases were obtained. The karyotype could not be determined due to the complexity and poor quality of the metaphases obtained. However, double minute chromosomes were observed, which is a cytogenetic hallmark of gene amplification. FISH for MDM2

e amplification. FISH for MDM2 showed a signal pattern, consistent with amplified MDM2. This is a feature of well-differentiated/dedifferentiated liposarcoma. Please correlate with other findings and contact the laboratory if FISH should be repeated on par
FISH should be repeated on paraffin tissue from the tumour.

The morphological appearances and immunoprofile are consistent with a solitary fibrous tumour.  Haemangiopericytoma is a less specific term, used in older literature, that described tumours that would currently be classified as solitary fibrous tumours, as

s solitary fibrous tumours, as well as, several other soft tissue neoplasms with similar staghorn vasculature.   Although histological features do not reliably predict behaviour in solitary fibrous tumours, the presence in this case of increased mitotic ac

s case of increased mitotic activity (8 per 10 hpf), possible tumour related coagulative necrosis and areas of moderate cellularity are findings associated with more aggressive (malignant) behaviour. The tumour, however, lacks other features associated wit
other features associated with malignancy such as infiltrative borders and significant nuclear pleomorphism.
-     Margins 9 o'clock <0.1mm, 3 o'clock 1mm (towards deep), deep 6mm, other margins well clear.

An abnormal clone with a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 2 and 14 was detected. Karyotypes with simple balanced translocations have been reported as a feature of some published haemangiopericytomas, but no recurrent translocation isdescribed.
nt translocation isdescribed. A breakpoint in 12q is a feature of some cases, but was not observed in this case. These results are consistent with, but not diagnostic for, haemangiopericytoma.

A.  Sections show the75mm tumour is a microinvasive thymoma which is difficult to morphologically sub-classify.   The mostly encapsulated tumour shows some organotypical features with angulated, mostly acellular, fibrous bands separating large lobules and

separating large lobules and sheets of tumour cells and there are some perivascular spaces.  Much of the tumour has a WHO type A morphology and comprises relatively bland spindle cells arranged in sheets, trabeculae with some micro-glandular/micro-cystic

micro-glandular/micro-cystic areas. Pericellular reticulin is demonstrated in these areas.  Round to polygonal epithelioid cells arranged in rosette-like structures are also present and compatible with type A morphology.  Alesser but significant component

sser but significant component displays micronodular thymoma with lymphoid stroma features with interconnected  nests of bland epithelioid cells and scant admixed lymphocytes separated by lymphoid rich stroma containing scattered lymphoidfollicles but no a

red lymphoidfollicles but no admixed epithelial cells.  There are multiple foci of definite capsular invasion (eg. Block A5, block A19) into adjacent mediastinal adipose tissue/thymic adipose tissue and no neighbouring mediastinal structures are present.

inal structures are present.  The invasive foci are predominately smooth contoured nodules with a micronodular thymoma and lymphoid rich stroma appearance. However, in some areas, the type A areas transitions to a minor component, including extracapsular t

ent, including extracapsular tumour, that shows a sheet-like arrangement of spindled to polygonal with at least mild atypia including irregular grooved nuclei, vesicular chromatin, conspicuous nucleoli and easily identified tumour cell mitoses (numbering u

mour cell mitoses (numbering up to 5 /10 HPF) (Block A10).  Focal lymphovascular invasion is present within the capsule of the tumour (Block A9).  No perineural invasion is seen.  The invasive tumour focally reaches the inked surgical resection margin (Blo

surgical resection margin (Block A 21, Block A6) and these areas show micronodular thymoma with lymphoid stroma morphology.  The capsule of the tumour also forms the margin of resection across a broad front.   No evidence of thymic carcinoma is seen.  No l

hymic carcinoma is seen.  No lymph nodes are identified in the loosely attached adipose tissue, however, a separate nodule of type A thymoma is present,  presumably microinvasive tumour,  is present here (Block A11). Two lymph nodes, present in theperithym
nodes, present in theperithymic adipose tissue, show reactive sinus histiocytosis but no evidence of malignancy.

Immunohistochemical stains confirm that the type A areas show relatively sparse mature CD3 and CD5 positive T lymphocytes with no immature T lymphocytes (CD1a, CD99 and TdT negative) and scattered CD20 positive B cells.  Scattered dendritic cells, includin

ered dendritic cells, including Langerhans cells (CD1a andS100 positive) are also present.  The micronodular thymoma with lymphoid stroma areas show restricted keratin (AE1/AE3) expression within the epithelial areas and  no keratin positive cells within t

eratin positive cells within the intervening lymphoid stroma. The lymphoid stroma predominantly comprises mixed mature T cells (CD3 and CD5 positive) and CD20 positive B cells.  There is also an admixed immature T cells (CD1a, TdT and CD99) component which

TdT and CD99) component which show accentuated distribution around the peripheral aspects of the epithelial nests.  The Ki-67 proliferation index is low within the bland type A spindle cells areas and  significantly higher within areas showing nuclear aty

thin areas showing nuclear atypia (Block A10).  The CD117 stains scattered cells within the epithelial component, possibly admixed mast cells, however, no sheet like pattern of positive staining is seen.  The CD5 stain appears to correspond to the CD3 stai
to correspond to the CD3 stain, highlighting T cells, without obvious CD5 expression within the epithelial cells.

The invasive thymoma is difficult to subclassify.  The tumour shows definite WHO type A areas and separate micronodular thymoma with lymphoid stroma areas. By definition these subtypes lack nuclear atypia.  However, the type A tumour appears to transition

tumour appears to transition to foci showing at least mild nuclear atypia and tumour cell mitoses. These areas don't quite correspond to typical B3 morphology of the WHO classification, as there are no squamoid features or raisinoid nuclear morphology.  I

isinoid nuclear morphology.  I am not sure if these foci represent the WHO spindle cell variant of B3 subtype.  According to the Suster Moran classification of thymomas, which divides thymomas into well differentiated, moderately differentiated and poorly

ely differentiated and poorly differentiated grading categories, and in which the poorly differentiated subtype corresponds to thymic carcinoma, the presence of cellular atypia and mitoses in this tumour warrants classification as a moderately differentiat
n as a moderately differentiated thymoma (atypical thymoma).   I will seek a second opinion from Prof. Z. Werblow at MOUNT PLEASANT HOSPITAL Hospital and a supplementaryreport will be issued.

I agree with your diagnosis of a thymoma with numerous foci of microscopic capsular invasion.  Subclassifing thymomas is somewhat subjective and some cases don't fit neatly into different diagnostic categories.  I favour this tumour being a type A thvmoma

tumour being a type A thvmoma (with areas of micronodular thvmoma with a lvmphoid stroma).  Although there are occasional mitoses in areas, the morphology is still similar to other areas and in my opinion, no convincing areas of type B3 thymoma are seen.
of type B3 thymoma are seen.  The significance of the focally increased mitotic activity and Ki-67 proliferative index is uncertain.

A and C. Sections show fragments of a cellular glial lesion and white matter. A small amount of grey matter is seen. The lesion is composed of tumour cells with irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei.  Scattered tumour cells with bizarre, giant nuclei and intran

zarre, giant nuclei and intranuclear inclusions are seen. No mitoses are present and the Ki67 proliferative index is low (2%). No definite endothelial proliferation or necrosis is seen. Hyalinised vessels with a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate are pres
ymphocytic infiltrate are present. There are no granular bodies, perivascular pseudorosettes or true ependymal rosettes.

The findings of a glial lesion composed of markedly pleomorphic tumour cells with low proliferative activity. Although no necrosis or endothelial proliferation is seen, in the context of IDH1 negativity and a glioblastoma in the opposite side, the findings
he opposite side, the findings would favour a glioblastoma (WHO grade 4). No convincing oligodendroglioma or ependymal differentiation is present.

B and D. Sections show fragments of glioblastoma (WHO grade 4), with small amounts of grey and white matter. The lesion is markedly cellular and is composed of moderately to markedly pleomorphic tumour cells, some of which contain intranuclear inclusions.
tain intranuclear inclusions.  The lesion has a Ki67 index of 20 to 30% with rare mitoses. Non-palisading necrosis and marked endothelial proliferation are also present.

This case was analysed for 1p/19q LOH using Vysis dual colour probe sets LSI 1p36/LSI 1q25 and LSI 19q13/19p13.  Cut-off values were adopted from Smith et al. 2000 (J Clin Oncol:18;636-645) who defined a 1p/1q ratio of <0.85 and a 19q/19p ratio of <0.9 as
nd a 19q/19p ratio of <0.9 as indicating LOH.  The case was also hybridised with Vysis LSI EGFR/Cep7 dual colour probe pair to assess whether amplification of EGFR was present.

57 year old man with a previous history of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid treated with resection and radiotherapy to the neck.  Now two separate intracerebral lesions, a complex enhancing lesion in the left posterior frontal periventricular white matte
al periventricular white matter with surrounding oedema.  A second exophytic non-enhancing lesion in the corpus callosum protrudes from the genu into the right frontal horn.

Thirty nine (39) slides labelled "62S02144 JUAN" were received including 2 intraoperative smears ("A" and "B"), 2 haematoxylin and eosin stained frozen sections ("F/S A" and "F/S B"), 11 haematoxylin and eosin stained paraffin sections ("AFS1", "BFS1", "C1

sections ("AFS1", "BFS1", "C1", "C1 recut 1-6", "C2", "Dl"), 2 sections stained for reticulin ("C1" and "D1"), 17 sections from block C1 immunostained for NeuN, chromogranin A, 68kD neurofilament protein, p53, GFAP (x2), synaptophysin, vimentin (x2), CD34

ptophysin, vimentin (x2), CD34, Ki-67, IDHIR132H, MIC2, pancytokeratin, CD68, EMA and TTFI, and 5 sections from block D1 immunostained for 68kD neurofilament protein, lDH132H, pancytokeratin, CD34 and TTFI.

Multiple fragments of tumour consisting of moderately pleomorphic elongated cells, predominantly arranged in interweaving bundles.  Scattered cells with nuclear pseudoinclusions are identified.  Mitoses are easily found and the Ki-67 labelling index is app

e Ki-67 labelling index is approximately 20-30%.  Foci of necrosis are present and there is prominent microvascular proliferation.  Compared to the right frontal tumour (see below) this lesion is more cellular and the cells more uniform and less pleomorphi
re uniform and less pleomorphic.

There is moderate granular membranous and some cytoplasmic MIC2 staining. CD34 stains endothelial cells.  There is a small amount of focal patchy interstitial staining, although this is much less prominent than in the contralateral lesion (see:below).  Sca
teral lesion (see:below).  Scattered strongly p53 : positive cells are noted, probably <5%. Compared to the contralateral lesion there are also more numerous weakly staining cells.

The majority ofthe tumour cells are negative for EMA although very rare cells, especially at periphery of several tissue fragments contain an EMA-positive paranuclear dot.  Stains for NeuN, chromogranin, synaptophysin, pancytokeratin, IDH1 RI25H and TTFI a
keratin, IDH1 RI25H and TTFI are negative.

The intraoperativesmear contains two populations of cells.  The predominant component consists of cells with large round or lobated nuclei of slightly different sizes with a thin, well defined nuclear membrane, uniformly granular chromatin containing sever

lar chromatin containing several chromcentres and often a prominent nucleolus.  Scattered binucleate cells are noted and a number of these nuclei also containing pseudoinclusions.  There is a minor component of relatively uniform cells with elongated round
orm cells with elongated round ended nuclei but no nucleoli.  Some -perivascular lymphocytes are noted but no vascular proliferation is seen.

The tumour is moderately cellular and pleomorphic.  Many of the tumour cells have medium to large round or lobated nuclei with a prominent nucleolus and a small amount of well delineated perinuclear clear to granular cytoplasm.  A number also contain nucle

.  A number also contain nuclear pseudoinclusions and several are bi- or trinucleate.  Scattered triangular cells with darkly staining amphophilic cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei are also included as are cells with large, hyperchromatic somewhat "smudg

hyperchromatic somewhat "smudgy" chromatin, cells with ovoid nuclei and perinuclear halos, and some with finely vacuolated cytoplasm.  Although a number of these cells resemble dysplastic neurons, stains for neural antigens including neurofilament protein,
cluding neurofilament protein, NeuN, synaptophysin and chromogranin are negative.

In some areas the interstitium is finely vacuolated and slightly basophilic, suggesting mucin.  There are scattered micro-cysts and very rare calcospherites.  No Rosenthal fibres or eosinophilic granular bodies are identified with haematoxylin and eosin. N
with haematoxylin and eosin. No ependyma is identified.

Perivascular chronic inflammatory cells are noted, often surrounding veins with some adventitial fibrosis.  There is no vascular proliferation or necrosis and mitotic figures are not identified.  The Ki67 labelling index is low (visually estimated at appro
w (visually estimated at approximately 2%).

Although in one fragment the tumour appears to be well demarcated from the surrounding dense paucicellular fibrillary gliosis, neurofilament antibodies highlight prominent axons bundles traversing the tumour.  These are accentuated adjacent to vessels.  In
uated adjacent to vessels.  In some areas beaded axons and axonalspheroids are also noted.

Special stains demonstrate perivascular reticulin only.  The GFAP staining is generally pale and most of the tumour cells do not show cytoplasmic immunoreactivity adjacent to the nucleus, although scattered GFAP positive processes are noted, especially adj
sses are noted, especially adjacent to vessels.  These processes do not radiate towards the vessels as seen in ependymal perivascular pseudorosettes.

In addition to normal endothelial staining there is very strong, uniform CD34 immunoreactivity between the tumour cells resulting in haloes of CD34 negative cytoplasm surrounding-tumour nuclei.  Included fragments of cerebral cortex show the expected norma

cortex show the expected normal endothelial staining.  Vimentin also shows prominent dark interstitial staining in many of the tumourfragments, although less intense than the CD34 staining, as well as some cytoplasmic staining.  Prominent activated microgl
.  Prominent activated microglia and scattered macrophages are noted within the tumour with CD68 antibodies. Approximately 4-5% of tumour nucleiare weakly p53 positive.

The right frontal lesion is a low grade glioma without high grade features and is best classified as a diffuse astrocytoma (WHO grade II).  However, a number of unusual morphological findings are noted, including the very limited GFAP staining and the stro
ted GFAP staining and the strong CD34 immunoreactivity, that are not typical of most WHO grade II diffuse astrocytomas.

Although limited or absent GFAP staining is described in some subependymal giant cell astrocytomas, there are no other features supporting this diagnosis.  Similarly, although CD34 immunoreactivity is a feature of many glioneuronal tumours and of pleomorph
ronal tumours and of pleomorphic xanthoastrocytomas, the other morphologicaland immunohistochemical findings in this case do not support these diagnoses.

The relationship between the left and the right frontal lesions is uncertain.  Although they are radiologically and morphologically distinct, suggesting separate lesions, the possibility of microscopic continuity or a common origin cannot be entirely exclu

rigin cannot be entirely excluded. FISH analysis to assess Ip and 19q polysomy and EGFR amplification will be performed on the left frontal glioblastoma.  If clinically indicated, further genetic analysis may be helpful.

This case was reviewed by Dr Arie Perry (Director of Neuropathology, UCSF) who agreed that the left frontal lesion is a glioblastoma (WHO grade IV).  He also agreed that the right frontal tumour is unusual but considered that the features were those of a l
the features were those of a low grade tumour, best classified as a diffuse astrocytoma (WHO grade II).

al resection margin. No obvious lymphovascular invasion is identified. Special stains (Reticulin and Perl's iron) reveal markedly thickened liver cell plates and absence of iron deposition within the tumour. On immunohistochemistry, the tumour shows positi

istry, the tumour shows positive staining with Hepar-1 and AFP, and negative staining with CK7 and CK20. Polyclonal CEA shows a canalicular staining pattern while CD34 highlights the endothelial-lined trabeculae of the tumour.

toses per 10 hpf.  Old blood undergoing organisation, areas of sclerosis and calcification are seen. No convincing birefringent amyloid deposits are present on Congo red staining.

m the margin.  There is no evidence of surface serosal involvement.

rom the margin.  There is no evidence of surface serosal involvement. The adjacent liver shows mild macrovesicular steatosis.

B.Sections show pieces of tumour tissue.  The larger piece has overlying dura.  No normal brain tissue is seen.  The tumour is similar to specimen A.  It consists mainly of spindle cells in short, haphazard fascicles.  Mitoses are frequent,numbering up to

are frequent,numbering up to 22 per 10 HPF, and some atypical mitoses are noted.  Some tumour cells have a single, prominent nucleolus.  The cells are predominantly spindle shaped but there are patchy areas of more plump, pleomorphic, atypical cells with

omorphic, atypical cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and better defined cell borders.  Some binucleate and multinucleate tumour cells are also noted.  There are patchy foci of tumour necrosis.  Tumour abuts and focally invades into and through the overlyin
into and through the overlying dura (block B4).

Reticulin stains show that most of the tumour is reticulin rich but a minor component has more scant reticulin.  The features are most consistent with a gliosarcoma.  The sarcomatous component is the predominant spindle cell tumour which is reticulin rich,

umour which is reticulin rich, while the high grade glioma (astrocytic) component has the more plump, pleomorphic cells and scant reticulin.  The high grade glioma component also shows more prominent and extensive GFAP positivity.  There is a merging of th
ity.  There is a merging of the glial and sarcomatous components.  A p53 immunostain is negative.  A Ki-67 stain shows a high proliferation index, estimated at around 80%.

The histology of the previous right parietal tumour (20S65987) has been reviewed and further reticulin and GFAP stains have been performed.  The previous tumour lacks the spindle cell appearance of the present tumour and reticulin is only around blood vess

ulin is only around blood vessels, not individual cells.  Also, it is generally GFAP positive.  The previous tumour is still considered to be a glioblastoma (WHO grade 4); no sarcomatous component is identified.

Specimen labelled "Tumour stomach" consists of a tubular segment of stomach 25 x 10 x 10mm with a nodule at one end 32 x 30 x 25mm.  The segment of the stomach has a T shaped stapled line.  The staples are removed and the margins are inked in blue and blac

The gastric tumour is a 32mm gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST). The GIST is predominantly circumscribed with a lobulated, pushing margin and expands the muscularis propria. The tumour is moderately cellular and is composed of bland spindled cells arra

d of bland spindled cells arranged in broad interweaving fascicles. In areas, the tumour cells appear moderately pleomorphic with variably sized nucleoli. There is widespread conspicuous paranuclear cytoplasmic vacuolisation. Centrally, the tumour shows pr

Centrally, the tumour shows prominent stromal oedema and hyalinosis. Mitoses are present up to 3 per 50 high power fields. Necrosis is inconspicuous. The tumour is largely surrounded by muscularis propria, but focally extends close to, but does not appear
close to, but does not appear to involve, theserosal surface. The tumour is clear of the gastric resection margins (0.56mm). The overlying gastric mucosa shows no significant histologic abnormality.

The morphologic and immunohistochemical features are consistent with a gastro-intestinal stromal tumour (GIST). Although the behaviour of these tumours can be unpredictable, individual tumours less than 50mm in size and with a low mitotic rate (less than 5
low mitotic rate (less than 5/50hpf), are typically associated with a low risk of aggressive behaviour (7th edition of the AJCC/TNM).

A. The sections show a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma consistent with cholangiocarcinoma.  The tumour surrounds the large bile ducts near the hilum.  Although most of the bile ductepithelium has been sloughed, atypical cells arising from the epit

al cells arising from the epithelium and forming papillary structures protruding into the duct can be seen (slide A5).  The tumour invades into adjacent liver and soft tissues and involves the caudate, left and right lobes.  Several small tumour nodules, m

everal small tumour nodules, many involving the portal tracts, are found distant from the main lesion (e.g., slide A 15 in the left lobe).  Malignant cells focally reach the capsular surface of the liver.  There is patchy chronic inflammation but no cirrho
nic inflammation but no cirrhosis in the liver.  Several irregularly dilated bile ducts are seen and atypical epithelial cells are present in occasional dilated bile ducts.

tumour has a heterogenous appearance.  In many areas, there are glandular structures with abundant fibrotic stroma.  Variable amounts of mucin formation are seen, highlighted by the PAS stain.  Inother areas, there are micropapillary structures or cribrifo

pillary structures or cribriform glands with central necrosis.  There is a variable degree of pleomorphism in the tumour cells.  The cytoplasm varies from clear to pale eosinophilic and is moderately abundant. The tumour cells strongly express keratin 19 a

strongly express keratin 19 antigen by the immunoperoxidase technique.  Keratin 7 antigen is also expressed but in a patchy distribution.  There is no convincing expression of Hep-Par 1 antigen. Membranous expression ofbeta catenin is present but not nucl

atenin is present but not nuclear expression of this antigen.  The tumour extends to the soft tissue resection margin over a 5mm front (block A5) and focally it is 0.3mm from the liver resection margin (block A6).  Tumour is foundwithin thin walled lymphov
oundwithin thin walled lymphovascular channels in the portal tracts but no tumour is found within major branches of the hepatic artery and portal vein.  Prominent perineural invasion ispresent.

No malignancy or dysplasia is seen in the vascular margin (slide A1) and common bile duct margin (slide A2). No definite malignancy or dysplasia is seen in the cysticduct margin (slide A16) but some of the tissue is distorted by diathermy artefact and diff
by diathermy artefact and difficult to evaluate.

B. Sections show skin with prominent solar elastosis excised to the level of underlying skeletal muscle. There is a 40mm malignant dermocutaneous tumour with similar morphology as that seen in the previous excision from MACQUARIEWARD Pathology (labelled 90

RIEWARD Pathology (labelled 90-BTNC 91552 Suga, Y 900750915;see also review report by Dr Y Halonen 90B75091). The tumour is composed of sheets and short fascicles of pleomorphic spindled and epithelioid cells as well as malignant multinucleated cells with

ant multinucleated cells with bizarre, hyperchromatic nuclei. Mitoticfigures are prominent. The appearance is that of a malignant dermocutaneous tumour with features consistent with a malignant melanoma. Malignant melanoma shows invasion into underlying sk
ws invasion into underlying skeletal muscle but no connection to the epidermis is seen. No obvious lymphovascular or perineural invasion is identified.

The overlying skin shows a scar in keeping with previous excision. The epidermis appears attenuated in areas with increased numbers of basal melanocytes displaying mild cytologic atypia. However, lentiginous proliferation of these melanocytes is not seen.
hese melanocytes is not seen. Subepithelial collections of lymphocytes are focally present but no definite features of a regressed melanocytic lesion are identified.

The sample wasanalysed for mutations at or surrounding codon 600 within exon 15 of the BRAF gene encompassing the region containing 97% of all BRAF mutations, using high resolution melting (HRM) analysis (Catalogue of Somatic Mutations in Cancer [1]).Abnor

Mutations in Cancer [1]).Abnormal HRM traces are subjected to DNA sequencing for characterisation. This assay is capable of detecting BRAF mutations providing the mutant allele is present at a level of 10% or greater.

BRAF mutations are found in 5-20% of colorectal cancers and 30-70% melanomas, in the majority of cases(90% in melanoma) the mutation results in the V600E protein change [1-2]. V600E specific BRAF inhibitors e.g. vemurafenib and dabrafenib have been develop

d dabrafenib have been developed to inhibit oncogenic BRAF in melanoma patients. Trials of these inhibitors have shown that melanoma patients with the BRAF V600K mutation may also benefit from treatment [3,4,5]. The presence of a BRAF mutation in colorecta
f a BRAF mutation in colorectal cancer can be used to rule-out Lynch syndrome and it also indicates that the patient will be insensitive to EGFR inhibitors e.g. cetuximab [6].

Reference articles: 1) Catalogue of Somatic Mutations in Cancer: http://www.sanger.ac.uk/genetics/CGP/cosmic/. 2) Garnett and Marais (2004) Cancer Cell; 6:313-319. 3) Chapman at al., (2011) N Engl J Med; (364)26: 2507-16. 4) Hauschild etal., (2012) Lancet;

auschild etal., (2012) Lancet; 380: 358-65. 5) Ascierto et al., (2013) J Clin Oncol 31: 3205-11. 6) Sharma et al., (2010) Arch Pathol Lab Med; 134:1225-1228. Reference Sequence GenBankAccession Number: BRAF NNM_004333.4.

The spindle cells are in haphazard fascicles and have large, pleomorphic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.  Mitoses are frequent, numbering around 20 per 10 HPF, and some abnormal mitoses are noted.  There is a small area of infarct-like necrosis in the n

infarct-like necrosis in the node but no other tumour necrosis is seen.  No differentiating features are identified with routine staining.  There is a moderate number of admixed benign small lymphocytes and plasma cells amongst the tumour cells.  There is

t the tumour cells.  There is some residual lymphoid tissue, with hyperplastic follicles, at the periphery of the node.  There is some probable extranodal tumour spread, with a pushing margin (blocks 23, 24) but soft tissue margins appear to be free of tum
rgins appear to be free of tumour.

The appearances are interpreted as a high grade sarcoma in a lymph node.  It stains S100 and Fascin positive and also shows some patchy CD68 positivity.  I favour this being a primary nodal sarcoma and the immunophenotype fits best with an interdigitating

best with an interdigitating dendritic cell sarcoma.  These are very rare tumours which most commonly present with solitary lymph node involvement.  The clinical course is said to be generally aggressive.

A.  Sections show a well circumscribed solitary hepatocellular tumour.  The tumour comprises of benign appearing hepatocytes arranged in solid sheets without acinar architecture.  The tumour cells are largerand paler than non-tumour hepatocytes in the surr

tumour hepatocytes in the surrounding tissue.  No central scars or large arteries are seen.  Focal areas of haemorrhage are present but no necrosis is seen.  Focal areas of fibrosis and septum formation are present.  The tumour is completely excised and is
r is completely excised and is well clear of the resection margin.

The tumour shows a well developed reticulum network (which is confirmed by reticulum stain).  The tumour cells are strongly positive for Hepar-1.  TheKi-67 proliferation index is about 2 to 3%.  CD34 is strongly expressed within the tumour.  The surroundin
in the tumour.  The surrounding liver tissue shows macro-steatosis.  There is no significant inflammation.  There is no evidence of architectural change or cirrhosis.

Sections show a solitary hepatocellular tumour (35mm), which is difficult to classify.  The overall appearances are favouring those of well differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma.  The main differentialdiagnosis is hepatocellular adenoma.  Hepatocellular

ular adenoma.  Hepatocellular carcinoma usually arises in the background of cirrhosis but no cirrhosis is seen here.  Hepatocellular adenoma is strongly linked to female contraceptive pills/steroids and male cases without linkage to contraceptive pills/ste
age to contraceptive pills/steroids are extremely rare.  This case will be sent to Prof Gerald SPANICEK of PROSERPINE HOSPITAL Hospital and a supplementary report will be issued.

I favour a diagnosis of well differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, rather than an adenoma, since the lesion has areas with thick trabeculae (>3 cells), focal loss of reticulin fibres, unaccompanied arteries and stromal invasion.  Focally there are a few
sion.  Focally there are a few pseudo glandular structures (dilated bile canaliculi).  Scattered mitotic figures arealso seen.  No vascular invasion is identified.

Specimen labelled "Abdominal tumour arising from the stomach"consists of a circumscribed nodule 95 x 90 x 90mm with a very small amount of gastric wall attached measuring 28 x 8 x 7mm.  Approximately 80% of the mass shows a peritoneal covering.  Sectioning

ritoneal covering.  Sectioning shows a solid cystic tumour containing haemorrhagic fluid and blood clot.  The cystic component shows a ragged inner surface.  The solid component has a uniform grey-tan cut surface and comprises 10% of the mass.  The solid c
10% of the mass.  The solid component is mainly present underneath the mucosal fragment.

The gastric tumour is a 95mm gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST). The GIST expands the subserosal tissue and appears circumscribed with a lobulated, pushing margin. The tumour is moderately cellular and is composed of bland spindled cells arranged in sh

spindled cells arranged in short fascicles with areas of intervening stromal hyalinosis, oedema and very focal necrosis. There is widespread conspicuous paranuclear cytoplasmic vacuolisation. Mitoses are present up to 5 per 50 high power fields. The tumou

0 high power fields. The tumour is 5.5mm from the gastric resection margin and extends close, but does not involve, the overlying serosal surface. The overlying gastric mucosa shows a mild to moderate non-specific chronic gastritis.
ritis.

The morphologic and immunohistochemical features areconsistent with a gastro-intestinal stromal tumour (GIST). Although the behaviour of these tumours can be unpredictable, individual tumours between 50 and 100mm in size and with mitotic rate of 5/50hpf, a
ith mitotic rate of 5/50hpf, are typically associated with a high risk of aggressive behaviour (7th edition of the AJCC/TNM).

Although the tumour cells have very similar morphology that seen in the previously diagnosed high grade urothelial carcinoma (L7 CONSULTING ROOMS: Q11478963), the immunohistochemical profile is different.  The urothelial carcinoma shows positive staining w
noma shows positive staining with CK7 and CK20, plus focal staining with CK5/6.  The CA125 stain is negative.

It is thus concluded that the current tumour may not represent a recurrence of urothelial carcinoma, but instead is favoured to represent a poorly differentiated mulleriancarcinoma.  As a normal ovary and fallopian tube are present, the tumour may be of pe
esent, the tumour may be of peritoneal origin.

here is no evidence of malignancy.

Sections show three separate subcapsular deposits of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma ranging from 10mm to 90mm in maximum dimension.  The deposits are predominantly composed of a cribriform or fenestrated arrangement of large malignant glands line

of large malignant glands lined by cells with moderately pleomorphic nuclei.  There is  prominent central necrosis within the complex large glands.  A lesser component of smaller malignant tubular glands is also present.  No definite lymphovascular invasio
efinite lymphovascular invasion is seen (some peritumoural retraction artefact and tumour carry over).

Away from the deposits the liver displays a normal lobular architecture.  The portal tracts contain a normal complement of bile ducts, hepatic arteries and hepatic veins and there is no significant portal fibrosis or inflammation.  Apart from minimal patch

ion.  Apart from minimal patchy macrovascular steatosis the hepatocytes are unremarkable.  An occasional portal Von-Meyenberg complex (bile duct hamartoma) is noted.  The gallbladder is essentially normal.

In the context of a rectal lesion the morphological appearances and diffuse CDX2 immunoexpression are compatible with metastatic rectal adenocarcinoma.  However, the presence of minimal patchy positive tumoural CK20 immunostaining and diffusely positive TT

ning and diffusely positive TTF1 immuonstaining is unusual for colorectal carcinoma.  Thelatter finding is more typically seen in lung adenocarcinoma or thyroid carcinomas but positive expression has been reported in a subset of colorectal adenocarcinomas

of colorectal adenocarcinomas with the TTF1 antibody used in this case (Novocastra SPT24 clone).  Further clinical and radiological correlation is advised. Comparison with the morphological appearances of the rectal biopsy may be helpful.
be helpful.

Comment: The posterior fossa tumour is a metastatic poorly differentiated carcinoma, favour adenocarcinoma. Melanoma and neuroendocrine markers are negative. PSA and TTF-1 negativity makes prostate and lung primaries unlikely, respectively.  CDX-2 is a mar

respectively.  CDX-2 is a marker of intestinal differentiation and can be seen in adenocarcinomas of GI tract, pancreas and biliary origin. CK7 positivity and CK20negativity makes an upper GI primary more likely. Correlation with clinical and radiologic f
with clinical and radiologic findings is required.

.  Mitotic figures are sparse, numbering up to 1 per 10 high power fields.  There is no necrosis.

A & B.  The sections of brain show sheets of highly atypical epithelial cells associated with abundant necrosis.  Islands of viable tumour cells are present in a perivascular location.  The tumour cells are arranged in solid sheets and there are so areas o
heets and there are so areas of pseudoglandular and papillary-like patterns.  There is marked nuclear pleomorphism and abundant mitoses, many of which are atypical.

The tumour cells show strong positive staining for CAM 5.2 but are negative for GFAP, consistent with metastatic carcinoma.  There is also positive staining for Keratin 7 and Oestrogen receptor.  Progesterone receptor is negative and the Oestrogen receptor
ive and the Oestrogen receptor staining is weak and focal.  TTF-1, CEA, Keratin 20 and P63 are all negative.  The P63 stain shows positive nuclear staining in a minority of cells within the tumour.

The histological appearances are consistent with metastatic poorly differentiated carcinoma.  The presence of Oestrogen receptor staining raises the possibility of origin from breast or female genital tract amongst other sites.  Staining for CA125 and WT1
.  Staining for CA125 and WT1 have been performed and are negative.  The CA125 shows very focal staining of uncertain significance.

The sample was analysed for mutations at or surrounding codon 600 within exon 15 of the BRAF gene encompassing the region containing 97% of all BRAF mutations, using high resolution melting (HRM) analysis (Catalogue of Somatic Mutations in Cancer [1]). Abn

Mutations in Cancer [1]). Abnormal HRM traces are subjected to DNA sequencing for characterisation. This assay is capable of detecting BRAF mutations providing the mutant allele is present at a level of 10% or greater.

BRAF mutations are foundin 5-20% of colorectal cancers and 30-70% melanomas, in the majority of cases (90% in melanoma) the mutation results in the V600E protein change [1-2]. V600E specific BRAF inhibitors e.g. vemurafenib and dabrafenib have been develop

d dabrafenib have been developed toinhibit oncogenic BRAF in melanoma patients. Trials of these inhibitors have shown that melanoma patients with the BRAF V600K mutation may also benefit from treatment [3,4,5]. The presence of a BRAF mutation in colorectal
a BRAF mutation in colorectal cancer can be used to rule-out Lynch syndrome and it also indicates that the patient will be insensitive to EGFR inhibitors e.g. cetuximab [6].

Reference articles: 1) Catalogue of Somatic Mutations in Cancer: http://www.sanger.ac.uk/genetics/CGP/cosmic/. 2) Garnett and Marais (2004) Cancer Cell; 6:313-319. 3) Chapman at al., (2011) N Engl J Med; (364)26: 2507-16. 4) Hauschild etal., (2012) Lancet;

auschild etal., (2012) Lancet; 380: 358-65. 5) Ascierto et al., (2013) J Clin Oncol 31: 3205-11. 6)Sharma et al., (2010) Arch Pathol Lab Med; 134:1225-1228. Reference Sequence GenBank Accession Number: BRAF NNM_004333.4.

ucinous neoplasm (disseminated peritoneal adenomucinosis - Ronnett / low grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei - Bradley).

n reactive pericolic lymph nodes are identified.

al cytoplasmic mucin, and flat to low villiform architecture. The mucosa is effaced, and in many areas, the mucinous epithelium rests on fibrotic tissue or muscularis propria. In the initial sections, there is a focal aggregate of organising mucin within t

e of organising mucin within the appendiceal fat. There is also focal mucin on the surface of the appendix which is not organising and is interpreted as surface contamination during specimen processing. There are no high-grade cytological or archictectural
cytological or archictectural changes.

B. Sections show high-grade serous carcinoma partially replacing the ovary. The carcinoma is characterised by papillary and solid architecture with slit-like glandular spaces, high nuclear grade and risk mitotic activity. Scattered psammoma bodies are iden

tered psammoma bodies are identified. There is focal ovarian surface involvement. There is no identifiable serous tubal intraepithelial carcinoma (STIC). The fallopian tube includes several cystic Walthard nests. The uninvolved ovarian parenchyma shows no
d ovarian parenchyma shows no specific pathology.

The AJCC eighth edition now defines M1a as intraperitoneal acellular mucin without identifiable tumor cells in the disseminated peritoneal mucinous deposits. There is limited literature data on the prognostic significance of acellular intraperitoneal mucin

cellular intraperitoneal mucinous disease The limited literature data suggest that patients with intraperitoneal acellular mucinous disease have a decreased risk of recurrence compared with patients with cellular disease and support the inclusion of a sepa
upport the inclusion of a separate M category for intraperitoneal acellular mucinous disease.

nge is also seen. Overall, the presence of cytologic atypia and brisk mitotic activity, is consistent with a smooth muscle tumour of uncertain malignant potential. However, given the presence of multiple foci of necrosis (?hyaline ?coagulative), as well as
line ?coagulative), as well as, patchy myxoid stromal change, a leiomyosarcoma cannot be entirely excluded.

Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch r
nactivation of that mismatch repair gene.

The features are those of an endometrioid adenocarcinoma with mucinous features and the PAX8 expression is consistent with a primary tumour. Some of the morphology features raise consideration of an endocervical rather than endometrial  primary. The epicen

dometrial  primary. The epicentre of the tumour cannot be determined due to its extensive nature, replacing the endometrium and much of the cervix.  An in-situ component is also not identified.   The immunoprofile is conflicting;  the Vimentin negative, al

ng;  the Vimentin negative, almost diffuse P16 expression is more typical of an endocervical primary while the strong diffuse ER (repeat stain pending) is more often seen in an endometrial primary.  Furthermore, this panel may not be reliable in distinguis

not be reliable in distinguishing endometrial from endocervicial  origin as the tumour shows variant (mucinous) morphology and the panel is more reliable in tumours with classical morphology. Therefore an endometrial primary cannot be excluded.  Further c
cannot be excluded.  Further correlation with the clinical features and previous pathology may be beneficial.

The adenocarcinoma present with the right ovary, uterus, omentum, peritoneal nodule , right side wall and bladder peritoneal nodule is consistent with metastatic disease with predemoniantly surface deposits.  The morphology  of the adenocarcinoma in the pa

f the adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, in the limited sample, is well differentiated but shows  morphogical features, including perineural invasion, dense hyaline stroma and small tubular glands compatible with pancreatic primary. High grade pancreatic intr

ry. High grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia is not seen, in the limited sample. The right ovary shows features of (mucinous) adenocarcinoma with varying differentiation (predominantly well to moderate with minor poorly differentiated areas). Areas

differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive in

ian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is ve

owever as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous

the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pa

tic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK1

d left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK19 and CDX2 expression) is identical and consistent with intestinal type differentiation.  In the absence of PAX8 expression ( seen in only about 30% of primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas but not in pancreatic primaries)

not in pancreatic primaries)  the immunoprofile is not helpful in determining origin of the disease.  This expression profile could also be seen in other upper gastrointestinal tract primaries.  The immunoprofile, with diffuse CK7 expression argues agains

e CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr X Maino who favours a pancreatic primary wit

vours a pancreatic primary with metastatic intraabdominal disease including to the ovaries. Dr Rogelio comments that the morphology in the larger left ovary, with extensive stromal desmoplasia, is more typical of metastatic disease and that intraabdominal

sease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) is es
r and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.

the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pa
